title: Should I open a new checking account prior to filing Chapter 7 Bankruptcy or is this not recommended?
question: I haven't had a checking account since it was frozen after a judgement against me about 10 years ago. I want to open an account with an online bank now because I just received an insurance settlement check but check cashing places want $500 to cash it which is outrageous plus issuing bank is refusing to cash it due to it being over their limit.
answers:
If you open a checking account, I recommend you choose a bank that is not one of your creditors. I also recommend you don’t open an account with Wells Fargo. In the past, they have frozen accounts where the owner is in bankruptcy until they receive notification from the trustee that the funds are exempt (protected). This means you could lose access to the funds in your account for some time. Do not bank with one of your creditors.

With respect to the settlement, not all settlements are protected so the type and amount matter. I recommend you speak with an attorney to make sure the settlement is exempt (protected).

"And I heard insurance settlements are off-limits to creditors so they can't touch it, right?"

I agree that you should contact a Bankruptcy Attorney near you to discuss the details of your case. Most Bankruptcy Attorneys offer a no obligation consultation. Many/most attorneys will accommodate phone/video consultations. Although, there are several factors to consider, it probably makes more sense to open a bank account for your insurance settlement, instead of paying $500 to cash the check.

Good Luck!

You have two questions. First, should you open a checking account before filing the bankruptcy. I would suggest you do so, as some banks have policies that make opening a banking account immediately after filing bankruptcy difficult. On the other hand, unless the bank will suffer a loss as a creditor when you file the bankruptcy, the account should remain open and available to

Second, while personal injury settlements can be protected by the exemption laws if you file bankruptcy, you have not indicated the reason why you received the settlement. Cash in the bank can only be corrected if it can be claimed exempt, either under the California wildcard exemption or traceable to another exempt source, i.e., Social Security benefits, 75% of wages earned within 30 days, etc. however, the wildcard exemption allows you to protect up to $30,825, which may very well protect the entire amount.

I agree with my colleagues, that you ought to consult with qualified bankruptcy counsel before committing to any course of action.
Before you do anything, talk to a bankruptcy lawyer to review your options, especially if you have an insurance settlement. Most of them offer free initial consults.

If any money if "off-limits" to creditors in a bankruptcy is something you need to discuss with the attorney who will be handling your bankruptcy, as there is almost nothing that simple in the bankruptcy court.
